How do I get the last lines of dust into the dustpan?

up vote 23 down vote favorite
5

While cleaning up my room with a broomstick, I use the dustpan to collect dust and garbage, but those last lines of dust don't go in the dustpan. That's why I have to leave it there.

How do I get the last lines of dust into the dustpan?

cleaning dust
share|improve this question
edited yesterday
rand al'thor
545213
asked yesterday
A J
240213
add a comment | 

7 Answers 7

active oldest votes
up vote 36 down vote accepted

Just keep sweeping the remaining line into the dustpan. It'll shrink more and more each time you sweep it, until in the end there's nothing left of it.

It also helps to change the angle of sweeping each time; that way, what was a long line becomes a shorter line relative to the new angle of direction.

share|improve this answer
answered yesterday
rand al'thor
545213
8  
+1 for the image – Ankit Sharma yesterday
1  
Also, sweep a few times in each direction and scoot the dustpan back an inch or so each time you sweep, so the dust isn't right against the edge of the dustpan, and has a chance to get swept up into it. – Zack 10 hours ago
    
I find the easiest thing in combination with this is to flick the dust into the air slightly, just enough to get it over the lip, instead of hitting the pan with the broom. – Tanath 6 hours ago
add a comment | 
up vote 26 down vote

This is a widely known lifehack. Use masking tape - just tape the front of the dustpan to the floor. It should cover the gap between the floor and your dustpan.

(Image taken from this Reddit thread.)

share|improve this answer
edited yesterday
answered yesterday
user31389
36124
    
Thanks for the image and idea. I'd definitely try that. – A J yesterday
2  
Incidentally, use the same approach when drilling holes in the wall for dust collection purposes :) – Immortal Blue yesterday
11  
Also, if you're sweeping a tile floor as shown in the picture, moving the dustpan to the grout line helps lower the dustpan lip to the same level as the tile and might eliminate the need for tape. – zundarz yesterday
12  
This seems like a lot of work, why not just tape over the line of dust on the floor (without the pan) then strip that up and throw that out? Like you are giving the floor a body wax to remove dust. – Captain Man yesterday
1  
@CaptainMan The tape may not always remove all the dust, depending on amount of dust and the size of the particles (e.g. sand doesn't stick very well to the tape). I would pick some other answers over that - either use a dampened paper towel/toilet paper or just scatter the dust if there's not much of it. – user31389 19 hours ago
 |  show 2 more comments
up vote 18 down vote

Just blow it back around the floor and pretend it never happened.

If a rug is available, traditionally you would sweep it under the rug.

Explanation: if it's not enough dust to sweep up it's not enough to care about.

I don't have any citations for this. It's a technique I came up with myself and I haven't documented it anywhere else. Maybe someone else has covered it, I can update if needed.

up vote 15 down vote

I use a hand held vac on the small particles of dust that won't sweep up.

My mother always dampened a paper towel and wiped up the dust that way.

Either is logical and works perfectly.

Why use the dustpan at all if you're going to use a vacuum? – David Richerby 4 hours ago

up vote 6 down vote

move the dustpan backwards when sweeping the last few bits into it. I've done this for years and it helps greatly. 2-3 of those usually gets it all.

share|improve this answer

up vote 4 down vote

Modern dustpans have evolved a compliant rubber lip that already assists with this task.

Using a feathered bristle brush with light downward pressure also moves the dust sideways over the lip instead of down and under the lip.

The bristle type I mean is illustrated in this car washing brush but common these days on those sold with dustpans as well.

share|improve this answer
answered yesterday
KalleMP
34016
add a comment | 
up vote 1 down vote

A sheet of paper can serve as a makeshift dustpan. Hold it in the middle on one of the long sides, giving it a slight crease with your thumb. When applied with gentle pressure, and at a rather steep angle, the leading edge should hold true to the floor.

No other technique using a broom can get more dust into the 'pan' and less into the air.

share|improve this answer
